At 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600, bowerypresents.com; $42.50 in advance, $45 at the door. (Jon Pareles)    BADLY DRAWN BOY (Wednesday and Thursday) Damon Gough, who records as Badly Drawn Boy, is an introverted, smoky-voiced, folk-rocking songwriter who's about to release his grand autobiographical statement, ''Born in the U.K.'' (Astralwerks). His concerts can be more like filibusters than shows, but there's talent amid the dross. At 7 p.m., Hiro Ballroom, 363 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-4300, bowerypresents.com; $20 in advance, $25 at the door. (Pareles)    EEF BARZELAY (Tuesday) With a homely, nasal tenor and a few lonesome strums on his guitar, Mr. Barzelay, the lead singer and chief songwriter of the band Clem Snide, can render heartache and regret with trompe-l'oeil precision or, if the mood strikes him, simply goof off. In one song on his latest solo album, ''Bitter Honey'' (SpinArt), he takes on the persona of a woman whose rear end makes an appearance in a hip-hop video: ''It was on screen for a second but was kind of hard to miss.'' With Casey Dienel and Kelley McRae. At 8 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $13 in advance, $15 at the door. (Ben Sisario)    BASEMENT JAXX (Wednesday) Basement Jaxx is an English disc-jockey duo that, happily, won't stay in any dance-music niche as it collaborates with all sorts of singers and songwriters. Its new album, ''Crazy Itch Radio'' (XL), dips into 1970's funk and soul, Balkan brass bands, updated swing and even banjo picking over a house beat. Onstage it keeps people dancing. At 9 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600, bowerypresents.com; $30 in advance, $35 at the door. (Tickets for Tuesday's concert, which was canceled, will be honored on Wednesday.) (Pareles)    * LINDSEY BUCKINGHAM (Tuesday) The skein of guitars on Fleetwood Mac's hits was devised by Mr. Buckingham, who also makes a solo album every 15 years or so. He's alone and overdubbed on most of the songs on his strange, folky new album, ''Under the Skin'' (Reprise). At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824, the-townhall-nyc.org; $41.50 to $61.50. (Pareles)    JUDY COLLINS (Monday) An intimate concert by the pure-voiced soprano who has been discovering songwriters since the 1960's. At 8 p.m., the Concert Hall at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, concertstonight.com; $45 and $55. (Pareles)    CONCERT TO CLOSE GUANTáNAMO (Tomorrow) A concert to protest the treatment of prisoners. With Marshall Crenshaw, Angelique Kidjo, Tom Paxton, the Klezmatics, Nellie McKay, Utah Phillips. the Mammals and others. At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 545-7536; $30 to $55. (Pareles)    EVANeSCENCE (Monday) Hard-rock riffs, grandiose keyboards and Amy Lee: this band, which struck it huge in 2003, revolved around the airy voice and emo-goth lyrics of its leader, the unabashedly theatrical Ms. Lee. At 6:30 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, mcstudios.com; $30. (Kelefa Sanneh)    GIPSY KINGS (Tomorrow) Strumming half a dozen guitars, singing in a husky rasp and stamping their heels on the floor, the members of this French pop group are to flamenco what Rice-a-Roni is to paella. Which is not to say that some of their international hits, like ''Bamboleo,'' aren't fiendishly catchy. Part of the New York Gypsy Festival, with Romashka, Dorit and the Russian Gypsy dancer Julia Kulakova. At 8 p.m., Roxy, 515 West 18th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-5157, roxynyc.com or nygypsyfest.com; $35 and $40. (Pareles)    GOMEZ (Tonight and tomorrow night) This British band emerged in the mid-1990's, the heyday of Britpop, with an against-the-grain obsession with tight, sharp blues-rock. On its newest album, ''How We Operate'' (ATO), it has veered into folkier realms, though it still plays with unusual precision and focus. At 8, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $27; tomorrow's show is sold out. (Sisario)    JOSÉ GONZÁLEZ, DEATH VESSEL (Tuesday) Mr. González, an Argentine Swede, plays haunting, austere confessions with precision guitar picking and a deadpan hush. As Death Vessel, Joel Thibodeau sings bittersweet, bluegrass-inspired elegies in a hauntingly high, almost feminine voice. At 8 p.m., Brooklyn Lyceum, 227 Fourth Avenue, at Union Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (866) 469-2687, brooklynlyceum.com; $15. (Sisario)    HAWTHORNE HEIGHTS (Sunday) This Ohio emo band is known for lightweight but sometimes likable songs; an infectious screaming refrain is never too far away. It is the headline act on the Nintendo Fusion tour, sponsored by the video-game company; the bill also includes Relient K, Emery, Plain White T's and the Sleeping. At 6 p.m., Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-1224; $22. (Sanneh)    INDIA.ARIE (Tomorrow) As her recent hit single insisted, India.Arie is more than her hair; she's the warmhearted, soulful voice of women trying to stay honest and think positive. Robin Thicke opens. At 8 p.m., Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070; $28.50 to $58.50. (Pareles)    ISIS (Sunday) Isis creates a fearsomely beautiful sludge out of atonal guitars and a permanently distorted bass. As it works its way to repeated climaxes, the music can feel like a glorious release or the last thrashings of a captured animal. At 9 p.m., Rebel, 251 West 30th Street, Manhattan, (212) 695-6115; $15. (Sisario)    ISLANDS (Monday and Tuesday) Islands generally stays on the bubbly, whimsical side of the psych-folk phenomenon, with song titles like ''Where There's a Will There's a Whalebone.'' Monday at 8:30 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15. Tuesday at 9 p.m., Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103, northsix.com; $15. (Pareles)    * ETTA JAMES (Wednesday and Thursday) Ms. James is a rhythm and blues empress, with a voice that remembers every stage of her life. She encompasses coy teenager and amorous woman, heartbroken lover and spiteful victim, party girl and desperate addict, all with sly timing and implacable assurance. At 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $87.50 general admission, $150 for reserved booth seats. (Pareles)    JIM LAUDERDALE (Tonight) This rangy-voiced singer has collaborated with everyone from the bluegrass patriarch Ralph Stanley to the jam band Donna the Buffalo, and on his 2004 album ''Headed for the Hills'' (Dualtone), he wrote songs with the Grateful Dead's lyricist Robert Hunter. With Carolyn Mark. At 7:30 p.m., Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; $12 in advance, $14 at the door. (Pareles)    *Audra McDonald and Friends (Wednesday and Thursday) This great theatrical singer, joined by two guests, Patti LuPone and Nellie McKay, stretches into the pop arena with songs from her newest album, ''Build a Bridge'' (Nonesuch). Thursday's concert will be broadcast on ''Live From Lincoln Center.'' At 8 p.m., the Allen Room, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Broadway and 60th Street, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; sold out. (Stephen Holden)    MERCYME (Sunday) Like a number of Christian rock bands, this one is known for a kind of yearning modern rock that wouldn't sound out of place on a secular radio station; the band has a following that many secular acts probably envy. With Audio Adrenaline and Phil Wickham. At 7 p.m., Nokia Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (212) 307-7171, nokiatheatrenyc.com; $40. (Sanneh)    JUANA MOLINA (Tuesday) A whispery Argentine singer-songwriter, Ms. Molina never rushes her lullabies, letting them swirl and melt, seductively drawing a listener in. With Adem. At 8 p.m., Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, near the Bowery, Lower East Side, (212) 533-2111, boweryballroom.com; $15 in advance, $18 at the door. (Sisario)    PORCUPINE TREE WITH PROJECkT SIX FEATURING ROBERT FRIPP AND ADRIAN BELEW (Tonight) Progressive-rock -- with its suitelike songs, complex meters and epic ambitions -- lives on in Porcupine Tree. Arrive early for Projeckt Six, featuring two of Porcupine Tree's inspirations: Robert Fripp and Adrian Belew, the guitarists at the core of the pointillistic, intense King Crimson lineup that began in the 1980's. At 8, Nokia Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (212) 307-7171, nokiatheatrenyc.com; $32. (Pareles)    LISA MARIE PRESLEY (Monday) Elvis's daughter and the ex-wife of Michael Jackson and Nicolas Cage has her say in troubled, semiconfessional rock songs that aspire to the sullen defiance of Garbage. With Joe Firstman. At 8 p.m., B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144, bbkingblues.com; $33.50 in advance, $36 at the door. (Pareles)    RATATAT (Tonight) The two guitarists who make up Ratatat have one simple but sometimes charming idea. They plug away at 1970's-inspired riffs, creating atmospheric tracks that split the difference between minimalist post-rock and maximalist hard rock. At 9, Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500, guggenheim.org; $20, cash only, at the door; free for members. (Sanneh)    SAY ANYTHING (Tuesday through Wednesday) Max Bemis, Say Anything's leader, wraps his troubles and doubts in high-speed punk-pop emo that also, now and then, has a tinge of Broadway swing. At 7:30 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com;$13.50 in advance, $17 day of show. (Pareles)    SOCIAL DISTORTION (Monday through Wednesday) Formed in 1978 by its songwriter, Mike Ness, Social Distortion plays punk-rock with a roots-rock twang. In his songs Mr. Ness is still trying to figure out the meaning of life, chronicling everything from anti-fashion stubbornness to feeling his age. With Supersuckers opening. Monday and Tuesday at 8:30, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800; sold out. Wednesday at 8 p.m., Warsaw, 261 Driggs Avenue, at Eckford Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 387-5252; $30. (Pareles)    ROD STEWART (Monday) After making four albums of old pop standards, Rod Stewart is applying his voice to rock: not his own, but other people's tried-and-true material, with an emphasis on ballads. For those who can't make the show, it will be shown at theaters nationwide the same night. At 8 p.m., Nokia Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (212) 307-7171; $75. (Pareles)    * Barbra Streisand (Monday and Wednesday) In her latest farewell concert tour, Ms. Streisand performs in the round with the pop-operatic quartet Il Divo. Expect to hear more than the usual number of Streisand rarities sung by a voice still in its prime. At 8 p.m., Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $104.50 to $754.50. (Holden)    ELAINE STRITCH (Tonight and tomorrow, and Tuesday through Thursday) The third autobiographical go-round by this feisty 81-year-old legend features 10 astutely chosen new songs (including the theme song from ''The Sopranos'') performed with verve and humor. But her between-song patter finds her at a loss to come up with amusing or enlightening new stories from her glittering show business life. At 8:45 p.m., Café Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $125; dinner required. (Holden)    K T Sullivan and Allan Harris This pleasant tribute to Johnny Mercer and Duke Ellington, celebrated as ''American Naturals,'' teams a zany charmer (Ms. Sullivan) with a Nat King Cole-like crooner. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11:30, and Tuesday through Thursday at 9 p.m., Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-6800, algonquinhotel.com; $50 cover charge a person, with either a $20 minimum or a $60 prix fixe dinner; dinner required at the first show tonight and tomorrow. (Holden)    * TOOL/ISIS (Tonight and tomorrow night) A double bill of hard rock with progressive-rock tendencies. In Maynard James Keenen's songs for Tool, angst, outrage, righteousness and disgust translate into aching melodies with complex, pummeling riffs down below. The hard rock of Isis churns and seethes before it eventually erupts. . Tonight at 8, Continental Airlines Arena, the Meadowlands, Route 120, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900; $23 to $57.50. Tomorrow night at 8, Nassau Coliseum, 1255 Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, N.Y., (631) 888-9000; $42 to $56.50. (Pareles)    TRIVIUM, THE SWORD (Tuesday) The hurtling double-bass-drum thrust and guttural vocals of thrash metal give way, now and then, to an actual melody in Trivium's latest songs. The Sword opens. At 7 p.m., Nokia Theater, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street, (212) 307-7171, nokiatheatrenyc.com; $18. (Pareles)    KT TUNSTALL (Tonight and tomorrow night) Ms. Tunstall reaches back to the folk-pop of the 1960's and 70's, with a big, bluesy voice and, now and then, an echo machine that helps her do dizzying things with it. At 7:30, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600; $25.25 in advance, $27.25 day of show. (Pareles)    * WOLF EYES; JOHN WIESE; THURSTON MOORE AND PRURIENT (Tonight) An all-star lineup of noise-rock. The members of Wolf Eyes, from Michigan, once described themselves as ''the Lynyrd Skynyrd of noise,'' and meant it: the group's rumbling, nightmarish clangor is in one sense a straightforward exposition of a kind of elemental rock artistry. The prolific John Wiese, from Los Angeles, has collaborated with pretty much everybody in this scene, including Thurston Moore, the Sonic Youth guitarist and art-rock figurehead. Tonight Mr. Moore plays with Prurient, a one-man noise machine from Providence, R.I. Also on the bill is Religious Knives. At 9, the Hook, 18 Commerce Street, near Richards Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (718) 797-3007, thehookmusic.com; $10. (Sisario)    * DWIGHT YOAKAM (Thursday) A honky-tonk country classicist, Dwight Yoakam writes terse, twangy songs that juggle heartache and resentment and sings them in a voice full of honeyed tension. At 8 p.m., the Concert Hall at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, (212) 874-5210, theconcerthall.org;$40 to $45. (Pareles)    Jazz    Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.    BALLIN' THE JACK (Sunday) This midsize ensemble, led by the clarinetist and saxophonist Matt Darriau, customarily spikes a swing-era repertory with madcap irreverence. That's especially true on this one-night stand, which features music from Marx Brothers film soundtracks, complete with Grouchoesque vocals from the alto saxophonist Roy Nathanson. At 9 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Nate Chinen)    ANDY BISKIN AND TRIO TRAGICO (Tonight) On his new album, ''Trio Tragico'' (Strudelmedia), Mr. Biskin presents a small chamber group consisting of himself on clarinet, Dave Ballou on trumpet and Drew Gress on bass. Their repertory ranges from melodic miniatures, by Mr. Biskin, to nearly open-form improvisation, collectively determined. At 9 and 10:30, Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)    RICHARD BONA (Tuesday through Thursday) Mr. Bona, the Cameroonian bassist and vocalist, has an appealing new album, ''Tiki'' (Decca), that confirms his commitment to musical globalism. He leads a six-piece group that includes the trumpeter Taylor Haskins, the keyboardist Etienne Stadwijk and the drummer Ernesto Simpson. At 9 and 11 p.m. and 12:30 a.m., Zinc Bar, 90 West Houston Street, at LaGuardia Place, West Village, (212) 477-8337, zincbar.com; cover, $5, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen)    MATT BREWER QUARTET (Tomorrow) The bassist Matt Brewer has lately distinguished himself in bands led by the saxophonist Greg Osby; this group features another adventurous saxophonist, Tony Malaby, along with Frank Locrasto on piano, and Rodney Green on drums. At 8 and 10 p.m., The Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)    * PETER BRÖTZMANN AND HAN BENNINK (Tonight) Few modern saxophonists can sound as powerfully abrasive as Mr. Brötzmann, and few drummers can seem as convincingly unhinged as Mr. Bennink. Each is a pillar of the European free-improvising scene, and a touchstone for the rambunctious wing of the contemporary avant-garde. At 7:30 and 9, Clemente Soto Vélez Cultural Center, 107 Suffolk Street, at Rivington Street, Lower East Side, (212) 696-6681, visionfestival.org; $20; students, $10 (Chinen)    RAY BROWN TRIBUTE BAND (Tonight through Sunday night) A tribute to Ray Brown, the quintessential jazz bassist, consisting of younger artists who had the chance to work with him: the singer Dee Dee Bridgewater, the pianist Benny Green, the drummer Greg Hutchinson and, slyly grinning in the hot seat, the bassist Christian McBride. At 8 and 10:30, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen)    JAMES CARTER ORGAN TRIO (Wednesday and Thursday) James Carter, the irrepressibly charismatic saxophonist, leads a sturdy and occasionally surprising soul-jazz unit with the Hammond B-3 organist Gerard Gibbs and the drummer Leonard King. (Through Oct. 14.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)    STEPHAN CRUMP (Wednesday) As a bassist and composer, Mr. Crump avoids obvious routes but manages never to lose his way, as he demonstrates on his intimate new album, ''Rosetta'' (Papillon Sounds). He celebrates the album's release by regrouping the two sensitive guitarists it showcases, Liberty Ellman (on acoustic) and Jamie Fox (on electric). At 9:45 p.m., Cutting Room, 19 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 691-1900, thecuttingroomnyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)    FESTIVAL OF NEW TRUMPET MUSIC (Tomorrow and Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) This series continues this weekend at Tonic with such sharp-minded trumpeters as Thomas Heberer (tonight) and David Weiss (tomorrow). Next week it moves to Cornelia Street Café, with up-and-comers like Bart Miltenberger (Tuesday), John McDonough (Wednesday) and Nate Wooley (Thursday). Tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501, tonicnyc.com; cover, $12 and $15. Tuesday through Thursday at 8:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Café, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $15, with a one-drink minimum. Detailed festival information is at fontmusic.org. (Chinen)    KENNY GARRETT QUARTET (Tonight and tomorrow night) Kenny Garrett is a bulldozer on the alto saxophone, which he applies toward blazing post-Coltrane calisthenics, and an introspective artisan on the soprano, with which he investigates East Asian folk timbres. His recent album on Nonesuch, ''Beyond the Wall'' was inspired by the ancient cultures of China and Africa. He'll revisit it with a band consisting of Benito Gonzalez on piano, Kris Funn on bass and Jamire Williams on drums. At 9 and 11, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)    DAVID GILMORE (Monday) Mr. Gilmore favors the clean guitar tone of George Benson, but his playing tends more toward an African rhythmic concept and a slippery melodic sensibility. He is performing with the all-star group from his new album, ''Unified Presence'' (RKM): Ravi Coltrane on tenor and soprano saxophones, Christian McBride on bass, Jeff (Tain) Watts on drums and, as a special guest, the vocalist Claudia Acuña. At 7:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778, joespub.com; cover, $15, with a two-drink minimum. (Chinen)    JIMMY HEATH'S 80TH-BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION (Wednesday and Thursday) The saxophonist and composer Jimmy Heath will turn 80 this month, and the Blue Note is celebrating the occasion next week with a five-night run replete with special guests. On Wednesday and Thursday, that means Bill Cosby, as host and M.C. (Through Oct. 15.) At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $35 at tables, $20 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Chinen)    JOHN HEBERT'S BYZANTINE MONKEY (Wednesday) This experimental ensemble features the original music and bass playing of John Hebert, along with the contributions of Tony Malaby and Michaël Attias, saxophonists, and Nasheet Waits, a drummer. At 10 p.m., Barbès, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Chinen)    GERRY HEMINGWAY/ELLERY ESKELIN DUO (Tomorrow) Texture outweighs tempo in Mr. Hemingway's drumming, and his compositions reveal a fruitful fascination with polytonality. Mr. Eskelin, a tenor saxophonist, has a predilection for expressive gruffness, but he tends to find the groove even in formless expanses. At 8:30 p.m., Center for Improvisational Music, 295 Douglass Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (212) 631-5882, schoolforimprov.org; cover, $12; students, $8. (Chinen)    FRANK KIMBROUGH (Tonight) Mr. Kimbrough is a thoughtful and harmonically literate pianist, with equal taste for melody and abstraction. He appears as part of a new Fazioli Salon solo piano series at the Klavierhaus workshop. At 8, Klavierhaus, 211 West 58th Street, Manhattan, (212) 245-4535, pianoculture.com; $20. (Chinen)    STEVE LEHMAN'S BLUEPRINT TRIO (Sunday) Steve Lehman, an alto saxophonist and composer, favors jagged intervals and surging rhythmic patterns in this working band, with Matt Brewer on bass, and Eric McPherson on drums. At 8 p.m., The Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)    TONY MALABY, WILLIAM PARKER, NASHEET WAITS (Sunday) A promising meeting of three accomplished yet restless improvisers, with experience both in and out of the avant-garde: Mr. Malaby, saxophonist; Mr. Parker, bassist; and Mr. Waits, drummer. At 8 and 10 p.m., Jimmy's No. 43, 43 East Seventh Street, East Village, (212) 982-3006, freestylejazz.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)    * BRANFORD MARSALIS QUARTET (Tonight through Sunday night) Branford Marsalis leads one of the most athletic working bands in the jazz mainstream, a point of pride he playfully acknowledges with the locker-room photograph on the cover of his new album, ''Braggtown'' (Marsalis Music). The ensemble -- with Joey Calderazzo on piano, Eric Revis on bass and Jeff (Tain) Watts on drums -- doesn't work often in clubs, which makes this engagement all the more significant. At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow night, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $35. (Chinen)    * BRAD MEHLDAU TRIO (Tuesday through Thursday) The pianist Brad Mehldau recently renovated the sound of his longstanding trio, with help from the powerfully expressive drummer Jeff Ballard. The group's luminous brand of lyricism has survived, but its repertory is slightly more pop-oriented, and its rhythmic tumble more pronounced. (Through Oct. 15.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)    PETE ROBBINS (Sunday) The choral music of the Italian Renaissance composer Carlo Gesualdo has recently provided inspiration for the creative energies of Mr. Robbins, an alto saxophonist and clarinetist. His ''Gesualdo Adaptations'' feature a modernistic ensemble of two saxophonists, two guitarists and an electric keyboard, along with bass and drums. At 8 p.m., Bar 4, 444 Seventh Avenue, at 15th Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 832-9800, bar4.net; suggested donation, $5. (Chinen)    * KURT ROSENWINKEL QUINTET (Tonight through Sunday night) Kurt Rosenwinkel's electric guitar has an airy tone that offsets the cerebral twinge of his compositions, and his rapport with the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner borders on the telepathic. The two musicians are backed by Aaron Parks on piano, Joe Martin on bass and Jeff Ballard on drums. At 9 and 11, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)    MATT WILSON QUARTET (Tonight) Mr. Wilson, a mischievous and nimble drummer, leads a rugged quartet with the trumpeter Jon Sneider, the saxophonist Jeff Lederer and the bassist Martin Wind. At 10, Detour, 349 East 13th Street, East Village, (212) 533-6212; cover, $5. (Chinen)    * A TRIBUTE TO RAY BARRETTO (Tomorrow) This salute to the conga player Ray Barretto, who died this year, features a version of his orchestra, with guests including the singers Adalberto Santiago, Tito Allen and Ray De La Paz; the percussionist Giovanni Hidalgo; the bassist Andy Gonzalez; the pianist Oscar Hernandez, who doubles as musical director; and the tenor saxophonist Chris Barretto, who follows in his father's footsteps as a jazz musician. Also on hand is the Machito Orchestra, led by Mario Grillo. At 8 p.m., Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, at Goulden Avenue, Bedford Park, the Bronx, (718) 960-8833, lehmancenter.org; $35 to $45. (Chinen)    Classical    Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.    Opera    'CARMEN' (Tomorrow and Thursday) Rinat Shaham, who made her company debut as Zerlina, is a small singer for Carmen; worse, the New York City Opera's production seems to have veiled her spark, rendering her a mere stereotype. Her Don José, Mark Duffin, has warm lower notes and a pressed, often flat sound on top; the Escamillo is Adrian Gans, who was too nervous to be judged at his company debut in the role. The high point is Latonia Moore, a radiant-voiced Micaëla who seems to belong to a world apart from this rather pedestrian production. Ari Pelto conducts, a little woodenly but competently enough. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $16 to $130. (Anne Midgette)    'L'ELISIR D'AMORE' (Tomorrow and Wednesday) The director Jonathan Miller updates Donizetti's lively comic opera from a rustic Italian setting to a 1950's American diner in this New York City Opera production. The cast includes Anna Skibinsky as Adina, and Erin Morley as Giannetta (both making their company debuts), John Tessier as Nemorino, Paulo Szot as Belcore and Jan Opalach as Dulcamara. George Manahan conducts the New York City Opera orchestra in Donizetti's tuneful score. At 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. (Vivien Schweitzer)    'FAUST' (Tonight and Thursday) Gounod's lush score is back at the Metropolitan Opera in Andrei Serban's staging, now less hyperactive than when it was introduced in 2005. Alas, someone appears to have gotten to its soul before Méphistophélès had the chance: the singers, though all fine, put the drama at arm's length, so the work's intense passions don't quite come through. In the cast: Ramón Vargas in the title role, Ruth Ann Swenson as Marguerite, and Ildar Abdrazakov as Méphistophélès, with Bertrand de Billy conducting. Tonight at 8 and Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $375. (Allan Kozinn)    'LA GIOCONDA' (Tomorrow) Grand opera does not get much grander or more theatrical or more violent than this. The traditional production by the Metropolitan Opera stars Violeta Urmana and Olga Borodina, with Marcello Giordani taking over as Enzo. At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000; metopera.org; $42 to $375. (Bernard Holland)    * 'IDOMENEO'  (Tuesday) Those who count on Ben Heppner to sing the heldentenor repertory may be surprised to hear him in the title role of Mozart's 1781 opera seria ''Idomeneo,'' staged by the Metropolitan Opera. But this role of the tormented king of Crete after the Trojan War has heroic dimensions, dramatically and vocally, which Mr. Heppner relishes in his clarion and compelling yet elegantly Mozartean portrayal. Other standouts in the cast include the exquisite soprano Dorothea Röschmann as the captured princess Ilia and the rich-voiced mezzo-soprano Kristine Jepson as Idomeneo's devoted son Idamante. James Levine conducts a refined account of a work he clearly loves. Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's elegantly stylized 1982 production is still handsome and effective. At 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $275. (Anthony Tommasini)    'THE MARRIAGE OF FIGARO' (Tonight through Sunday) Now in its 59th season, the Amato Opera continues to stage productions in its charmingly tiny quarters on the Bowery. This weekend it continues its run of Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' with a rotating cast. The quality varies and depends largely on who is singing that night, but the spirit is often there. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 228-8200, amato.org; $35; $28 for students and 65+. (Schweitzer)    'THE MERRY WIDOW' (Tomorrow and Sunday) The enterprising Dicapo Opera Theater has some ambitious productions lined up for this season, including a revised version of ''Thérèse Raquin'' by Tobias Picker, who composed ''An American Tragedy'' for the Metropolitan Opera. But Dicapo opens its season with a new production by Michael Capasso of the frothy, tuneful and worldly-wise Franz Lehár operetta ''The Merry Widow.'' The production will use spoken dialogue that was essentially rewritten by the playwright Wendy Wasserstein. Constantine Kitsopoulos conducts. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 4 p.m., Dicapo Opera Theater, 184 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 288-9438, dicapo.com; $47.50. (Tommasini)    'DIE TOTE STADT' (Sunday) The composer Erich Wolfgang Korngold is best known for his pioneering scores for swashbuckling Hollywood films of the 1930's. But in Germany in 1920, at the age of 24, he was hailed as the brilliant and promising composer of a mysterious opera, ''Die Tote Stadt.'' The New York City Opera, which has been a champion of this neglected work, has revived its 1975 production, which incorporates film elements, video projections and scrims to evoke the dreamlike story. The cast, though not ideal, is appealing, and George Manahan conducts a sweeping account of Korngold's lyrically sumptuous and theatrical music. At 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $25 to $125. (Tommasini)    'DIE ZAUBERFLOTE' (Tomorrow and Monday) Julie Taymor's production of Mozart's fairytale opera ''Die Zauberflöte,'' introduced in 2004, did not please everyone, including this critic. But overall it was an enormous hit with Met audiences. To me the production was so packed with nonstop stage effects, so overly busy and so peopled with dancers, extras, gargantuan puppets and kitelike animals of every sort that the fine musical performances by the conductor James Levine and cast took a back seat to the stage show. The conductor Scott Bergeson takes the podium for the Met's current revival. The promising cast includes Isabel Bayrakdarian as Pamina, Jonas Kaufmann as Tamino and Nathan Gunn as Papageno. Tomorrow at 1:30 and Monday at 7:30, the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $375. (Tommasini)    Classical Music    BARGEMUSIC (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) This converted coffee barge is one of the most intimate chamber music halls in the city, and its programs are growing more varied all the time. Tonight Katya Mihailova, a pianist; William Harvey, a violinist; and Chris Gross, a cellist, play piano trios by Haydn, Dvorak and Adolphus Hailstork. Tomorrow and Sunday another ensemble -- Naoko Tanaka, a violinist; Masao Kawasaki, a violist; Joseph Lee, a cellist; and Rita Sloan, a pianist -- play Mozart's Piano Quartet No. 1 (K. 478) and works for violin and piano by Mozart and Shostakovich. And on Thursday the pianist Hamish Milne plays Bach's Partita No. 4, Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109) and works by Medtner and Chopin. Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday nights at 7:30; Sunday at 4. Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083, bargemusic.org; $35; $20 for students; $30 for 65+ tonight and Thursday only. (Kozinn)    BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Monday) To start its Carnegie Hall appearances in James Levine's third season as music director, the orchestra is performing the Viennese Schools, first and second, in two piano concertos, one by Beethoven (the fourth), one by Schoenberg. Both feature as soloist another conductor with a wide and ambitious range, Daniel Barenboim. Also on the program is the string-orchestra version of Schoenberg's ''Verklärte Nacht.'' At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $39 to $127. (Midgette)    CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Thursday) If you think that the Chamber Music Society's usual home, Alice Tully Hall, is too big for this intimate repertory, here's a chance to hear the ensemble in closer confines. Stephen Taylor, the oboist; Jose Franch-Ballester, the clarinetist; Peter Kolkay, the bassoonist; Stewart Rose, the hornist; and Inon Barnatan, the pianist, recombine in various configurations to play the Francaix Divertissement, the Poulenc Trio and Beethoven's Quintet in E flat for Winds and Piano (Op. 16). At 6:45, the Rose Studio, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; sold out. (Kozinn)    * VLADIMIR FELTSMAN (Tuesday and Thursday) In a surprising shift from his modern piano comfort zone, this thoughtful artist is performing all of Mozart's piano sonatas on a modern copy of a Mozart-era Walter fortepiano. The five recitals are split between the New School and the Mannes College of Music. In the final two installments, Mr. Feltsman will play the Sonatas in F (K. 533), C (K. 545) and C minor (K. 457), and the Fantasia in C minor (K. 475), on Tuesday at Mannes; he will perform the Sonatas in B flat (K. 570) and D (K. 576), as well as the Fantasia in D minor (K. 385), the Rondo in D (K. 485) and the Adagio in B minor (K. 540) on Thursday at the New School. At 7:30, Mannes College of Music, 150 West 85th Street, Manhattan, and the New School, 66 West 12th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 229-5488, newschool.edu/feltsman; sold out. (Kozinn)    BEN HEPPNER/WENDY BRYN HARMER/CRAIG RUTENBERG (Thursday) For its recital series, the George London Foundation pairs established vocal stars with young recipients of the foundation's annual award. Pairing Ms. Harmer, a soprano, with Mr. Heppner, a popular tenor, has paid off: the event is already sold out. At 7:30 p.m., Morgan Library, 225 Madison Avenue (36th Street), (212) 685-0008, www.themorgan.org. (Midgette)    THE JUILLIARD ORCHESTRA (Thursday) This excellent band of polished young musicians will show what they can do with Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 in A; Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 in B-flat minor, with Konstantin Soukhovetski as soloist; and Richard Strauss's Wiener Philharmoniker Fanfare. James DePriest, Juilliard's director of conducting and orchestral studies, leads the program. At 8 p.m., Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Juilliard School, Broadway at 65th Street, (212) 769-7406, www.juilliard.edu; free. (Schweitzer)    LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Tomorrow) The orchestra's Beethoven cycle with Bernard Haitink begins with the Second and Third Symphonies and will continue through the week. If recordings are an indication, these should be honest, sturdy and ultimately winning performances. At 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $85. (Holland)    LEON MCCAWLEY (Sunday) This British pianist is active across Europe, but has not yet been heard in recital in New York. He will perform a few signature pieces, including a suite by Hans Gál, an émigré Austrian composer whose complete piano works Mr. McCawley has recorded, and the K. 311 sonata by Mozart. (A complete sonata cycle is due out soon.) The program also includes Schubert's D. 537 sonata and some pieces by Rachmaninoff. At 5 p.m, Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 547-0715, frick.org; $25. (Midgette)    * NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Tonight) Lorin Maazel leads the Philharmonic in its second complete performance of Ravel's one-act opera ''L'Enfant et les Sortilèges.'' (The first performance was yesterday.) The soprano Patrizia Ciofi is making her Philharmonic debut; the mezzo-soprano is Susanne Mentzer. The lineup also includes the soprano Jessica Jones, the mezzo-sopranos Isabel Leonard and Kelley O'Connor, the baritone Ian Greenlaw, the tenor Philippe Castagner (all making their Philharmonic debuts) and the bass Kevin Deas. The second half of the program features Saint-Saëns's Symphony No. 3, ''Organ.'' The Philharmonic's organist, Kent Tritle, is the soloist. At 8, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org; $28 to $94. (Schweitzer)    * ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKE'S (Thursday) The Bach specialist Mary Dalton Greer conducts the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the New York Baroque Soloists in ''Bach Dialogues for Soprano and Bass,'' the first of three programs in the ''Cantatas in Context'' series, now in its seventh season. Dominique Labelle, a soprano, and Christopheren Nomura, a baritone, will sing Bach's ''Liebster Jesu, mein Verlangen'' (BWV 32), ''Ich geh und suche mit Verlangen'' (BWV 49) and ''Ach Gott, wie manches Herzeleid'' (BWV 58). At 7:30, St. Bartholomew's Church, 109 East 50th Street, Manhattan, (212) 378-0248, oslmusic.org; $25 to 35. (Schweitzer)    PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA (Tuesday) The orchestra pays one of its regular visits to Carnegie Hall with Tchaikovsky's ''Pathétique,'' conducted by Christoph Eschenbach, and the challenging Brahms Second Piano Concerto, with André Watts as soloist. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $29 to $100. (Holland)    DOROTHEA RÖSCHMANN/GRAHAM JOHNSON (Thursday) In recital, American singers tend to want to show their versatility (''Look, Ma, I can sing in five languages!'') This fine German soprano is, by contrast, sticking to her home language with an all-Viennese program. She strays afield only with some of Schubert's Scottish songs -- including all three of ''Ellen's Gesänge,'' one of which is better known as ''Ave Maria.'' The program also includes a set of Mahler and Berg's ''Sieben frühe Lieder.'' At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $29 to $42. (Midgette)    PETER SERKIN (Wednesday) This enterprising and distinguished pianist mixes music by Bach and Toru Takemitsu in another of his mind-bending evenings of contrast. At 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $40 to $48. (Holland)    Dance    Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.    BRIAN BROOKS MOVING COMPANY (Tonight and tomorrow night) Brian Brooks is known for his intricate meshing of form and exuberant physicality. His new ''again, again'' explores the notion of grabbing hold of fleeting moments as they slip by. At 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org; $20. (Jennifer Dunning)    CHEZ BUSHWICK (Tomorrow) Jonah Bokaer's Chez Bushwick, one of the hippest places to see dance in New York City today, will present ''Ambush,'' a program of works by 10 artists, including Yasuko Yokoshi and Levi Gonzalez. At 8 p.m., Rooftop, 57 Thames Street, Bushwick, Brooklyn, (718) 418-2509, officeops.org; $5. (Dunning)    DANCE THEATER ETCETERA (Tomorrow) Dancers, musicians and visual installations will guide the audience through an unusual two-hour tour of the historic Green-Wood Cemetery, choreographed by Martha Bowers, complete with angels. At noon and 3:30 p.m., Green-Wood Cemetery, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 788-7850, green-wood.com; free. (Dunning)    DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP (Tuesday through Thursday) The American component of an international festival based in the Netherlands presents a showcase of stylistically varied choreography: Nora Heilmann on Tuesday at 5:30 p.m.; Ivana Muller and Daria Buzovkina on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m.; Eduard Gabia and Chris Yon on Thursday at 7:30 p.m. (Through Oct. 14.) Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077, dtw.org. Tuesday, free; Wednesday and Thursday, $20; artists, students and 65+, $12. (Jack Anderson)    * ANNE TERESA DE KEERSMAEKER AND AKRAM KHAN (Tonight and tomorrow night) Part of the citywide, mostly musical ''Steve Reich @ 70'' celebration, this program offers two of Europe's best-known choreographers with dances to Mr. Reich's music: Ms. De Keersmaeker's ''Fase,'' from 1982, and Mr. Khan's ''Variations for Vibes, Pianos and String'' in its United States premiere. At 7:30, Howard Gilman Opera House, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $20 to $55. (John Rockwell)    * FALL FOR DANCE (Tonight through Sunday) Only in its third year but clearly the king of New York's late summer/early fall dance samplers, Fall for Dance winds up its newly expanded, 10-performance schedule. Tonight's program has Peter Boal's Pacific Northwest Ballet, Christopher Williams and three others; the Saturday and Sunday bill offers Elizabeth Streb, Aszure Barton, the Ballet Boyz and two more. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 2 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; $10. (Rockwell)    FOLK FEET: CIRCLE 'ROUND BROOKLYN (Sunday) The focus will be on the old folk tradition of circle dancing in this day of workshops and performances by troupes from around the world, including Brooklyn. From 2 to 5 p.m., Tobacco Warehouse, Empire-Fulton Ferry State Park in the Brooklyn Bridge Park, (718) 625-0080, brooklynartscouncil.org; free. (Dunning)    * SYLVIE GUILLEM AND RUSSELL MALIPHANT (Wednesday) Ms. Guillem, a star French ballerina now segueing into modern dance, joins forces with Mr. Maliphant, the British dancer and choreographer, for a four-part program called ''Push,'' the first result of the newly announced collaboration between City Center and the Sadler's Wells Theater in London. There will be two Guillem solos, one Maliphant solo and a duet. (Through Oct. 15.) At 7:30 p.m., City Center, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan, (212) 581-1212, nycitycenter.org; $35 to $85. (Rockwell)    LIZ LERMAN DANCE EXCHANGE (Tonight through Monday) Liz Lerman, who creates choreography notable for its humanistic content and its concern for social problems, presents excerpts from ''Small Dances About Big Ideas,'' commissioned by the Harvard Law School. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 and 8 p.m., Monday at 8 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway (second floor), at Chambers Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com; $25. (Anderson)    LIGHTCURVE DANCE AND MIXED MEDIA (Tonight through Sunday night) ''Panicky Mechanical Loam Realm'' blends lucid movements with ethereal costumes, layers of video projections and a collage of sounds. At 8, Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479, joyce.org/soho.html; $15; $12 for students and 65+. (Anderson)    LYON OPERA BALLET (Tonight and tomorrow night) In its only New York City-area performance this season, the Lyon company will perform two different programs featuring ballets by William Forsyth; the company director, Maguy Marin; and Sasha Waltz; with two views of Beethoven's Grosse Fugue in choreography by Ms. Marin and Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker. At 8, Performing Arts Center, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6200, artscenter.org; $35 to $55. (Dunning)    NEW YORK BAROQUE DANCE COMPANY (Today) The company will perform ''An Entertaining Assembly for George Washington,'' a half-hour period concert in the style of a dance ball, which includes a game of Blind Man's Buff performed to ''Yankee Doodle.'' At noon, Federal Hall National Monument, 26 Wall Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 662-8829, nybaroquedance.org; free. (Dunning)    NICHOLASLEICHTERDANCE (Wednesday) High-energy and hip choreography in a style that blends modern and club dance, in a program of work by Nicholas Leichter. At 8 p.m., World Financial Center at the Winter Garden, 220 Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505, worldfinancialcenter.com; free. (Dunning)    PHILADANCO (Tonight through Sunday) Works by Ronald K. Brown, Christopher Huggins and Danny Ezralow headline this Philadelphia troupe's return to the Joyce, but the dancers' rich, energetic interpretations promise to be the highlight. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m.; the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800; $40. (Claudia La Rocco)    RENNIE HARRIS' NEW YORK LEGENDS OF HIP-HOP (Tonight through Sunday, and Thursday) The multitudinous aspects of a musical and choreographic form that spread from city streets into theaters will be explored in performances by Mr. Harris, Pop Master Fabel, the Rock Steady Crew, the Mop Tops and others. (Through Oct. 22.) Tonight at 7, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Sunday at noon and 5 p.m., Thursday at 7 p.m., New Victory Theater, 209 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 239-6200, newvictory.org; $35, $25 and $12.50. (Anderson)    SUGAR SALON (Tuesday) Susan Marshall and Company, Yanira Castro and Company, Ivy Baldwin Dance and Dana Ruttenberg offer world premieres. At 8 p.m., Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400 or symphonyspace.com; $20. (Anderson)    WORLD MUSIC INSTITUTE (Tonight) Pandit Birju Maharaj, known as a master interpreter the subtle North Indian classical dance form Kathak, appears in the institute's Festival of India with Saswati Sen, another Kathak star. At 8, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 545-7536, worldmusicinstitute.org; $35 and $45. (Dunning)    YAA SAMAR! DANCE THEATER (Thursday) Samar Haddad King's works use images of water, ice and light to express themes of religious conflicts and mental and physical awakenings. (Through Oct. 15.) At 8 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479, joyce.org/soho.html; $15; $12 for students and 65+. (Anderson)    Art    Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.         Museums    * Asia society: 'ONE WAY OR ANOTHER: ASIAN AMERICAN ART NOW,' through Dec. 10. Taking its name from a 1978 hit by the punk band Blondie, this lively exhibition finds a new vitality and freedom, especially where identity is involved, in Asian-American art. The artists' roots range from Iran to Korea; their mediums include painting, drawing, sculpture, video, photography and performance. Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 517-2742, asiasociety.org. (Roberta Smith)    Brooklyn Museum: 'Looking Back from Ground Zero: Images from the Brooklyn Museum Collection,' through Jan 7. This show presents a historical picture of Lower Manhattan from early on to the present, with the building of the World Trade Center as the pivotal point. A short film, ''Building the World Trade Center,'' produced by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 1983, is an invaluable document of the triumphalist spin surrounding the construction of the complex. A small selection of artworks produced in or just after 2001 hints at the profound and conflicted feelings the destruction of the twin towers has evoked. 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org.(Holland Cotter)    International Center of Photography: 'Ecotopia: The Second I.C.P. Triennial of Photography and Video,' through Jan. 7. Punctuated by big black oozing forms that are both comic and ominous, this edifying, entertaining, ecologically aware exhibition is a walk-through version of Al Gore's ''Inconvenient Truth.'' The work on view represents nearly 40 artists and photojournalists and portrays nature as variously ravishing, cute and enduring, and also increasingly dangerous and endangered, thanks to the widening scope of human indifference and exploitation. International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org. (Smith)    * Metropolitan Museum of Art: 'Brush and Ink: The Chinese Art of Writing,' through Jan. 21. If painting and writing can be seen as modes of thinking, and they can, then this exhibition is as much a brainstorming session as an art exhibition, crackling with ideas and arguments every step of the way. It is also a sequence of moods, with impassioned voices calling out from the 80 scrolls and inscribed fans that line the galleries, which include colossal examples of contemporary 21st-century art that both depart from and preserve a tradition, (212) 535-7710, metmuseum.org. (Cotter)    * the MET: 'SEAN SCULLY: WALL OF LIGHT,' through Jan. 15. The capacious, day-lighted mezzanine galleries at the Met are the perfect setting for Sean Scully's bold and energizing ''Wall of Light'' paintings from the series he started in 1998. These large-scale oils on canvas wow the viewer with their scale, intensity of color and sheer dominance of space. All have this in common: They are richly painted surfaces of close-laid vertical and horizontal bars (he calls them bricks) whose arrangement suggests constructed walls of stone. Paint disports in the tiny crevices between the bars to give an effect of luminosity. Although they appear totally abstract, with their all-over arrangements of bars that superficially vary only in color, size and juxtaposition, they evoke landscapes, people, events, the work of other artists. (See above.) (Grace Glueck)    * the MET: SET IN STONE: THE FACE IN MEDIEVAL SCULPTURE, through Feb. 19. One of those revelatory close-ups at which the Metropolitan Museum of Art excels, this show brings together nearly 80 carved, mostly limestone heads, mostly from the 12th and 13th centuries, mostly torn during bouts of iconoclasm from the sculptures and reliefs that turned Gothic cathedrals and abbey churches into Bibles in stone. The treatments of hair and beard with which medieval sculptors were more at ease than they were with, say, eyes or smiles, are almost a show within a show, as, in their own way, are the haunting, seemingly modernist works that look like nothing else here. (See above) . (Smith)    RUBIN MUSEUM OF ART: 'I SEE NO STRANGER: EARLY SIKH ART AND DEVOTION,' through Jan. 29. Sikhism is the world's fifth-largest organized religion, but how many Westerners know that it was conceived as universalist in scope and radically egalitarian socially? Or that its holy book, far from being a catalog of sectarian dos and don'ts, is a bouquet of poetic songs blending the fragrances of Hindu ragas, Muslim hymns, and Punjabi folk tunes? This is precisely the information delivered by this small and beautiful show. Vivid and concentrated, it presents, mostly through miniature paintings, a kind of Sikh self-portrait, the image of a history shaped by hard work, pluralism and mystical transport, as well as by militancy. 150 West 17th Street, Chelsea, (212) 620-5000, rmanyc.org. (Cotter)    * The Whitney Museum of American Art: Mark Grotjahn, through Jan. 7. Mining the early Modernist cusp where the figurative, the geometric, the spatial and the visionary still remain tangled, this Los-Angeles-based painter deploys his abstract pinwheel motifs on paper in eight brash, door-sized drawings. Multiple vanishing points destabilize radiating compositions that are variously Op and buzzy, darkly monochrome (and a little too pretentiously moody) or candy-color bright. In some works the motif is doubled and angled, decreasing the shield-like frontality and opening up new optical and spatial possibilities. 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600, whitney.org. (Smith)    The Whitney Museum of American Art: 'Picasso and american art,' through Jan. 28. Notwithstanding the glamorous pictures in it, this is one of those dull affairs incubated in the world of academe: a walk-through slide show that states the obvious. Picasso's ''Woman in White,'' a picture of heavenly arrogance, hangs between Arshile Gorky's ''Artist and His Mother'' and de Kooning's ''Standing Man,'' terrific paintings too. We are meant to register the plain insinuation of Picasso's neo-Classicism, then move on. Next slide, please. The show ends with a virtual retrospective of Picasso-inspired works by Jasper Johns. In picture after picture, Johns buries allusions to the great Spaniard, aspiring presumably to Picasso's own late meditations on Velázquez. Except that even when he was old and running out of steam, Picasso still had joie de vivre. Johns doesn't so much enthrone Picasso as repeatedly entomb him. See above. (Michael Kimmelman)    Galleries: Chelsea    Ken Gonzales-Day In the process of researching a book called ''Lynching in the West: 1850-1935,'' this Los Angeles artist assembled an archive and made a discovery: in the more than 350 California lynchings he found records for, most of the victims were Latinos. His photographic show at Cue Foundation is an interpretive response to this fact, largely through altered historical photographs, in which the hanged figure is erased, and the spectators left intact. Cue Art Foundation, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 206-3583, cueartfoundation.org, through Oct. 14. (Cotter)    Dona Nelson The painter Dona Nelson is in midcareer, and her work process is more experimental than ever, on the evidence of the four large pieces in this show. One is made with layers of hosed-down pigment; another is festooned with ropes of stiffened cloth; a third is a rubbing from an earlier painting; a fourth is reversible. In messing around with form, Ms. Nelson lets beauty fall where it may, which makes her art feel exciting and awake. Thomas Erben Gallery, 526 West 26th Street, fourth floor, (212) 645-8701, thomaserben.com, through Oct. 21. (Cotter)    * RIVANE NEUENSCHWANDER: 'OTHER STORIES AND STORIES OF OTHERS' The New York gallery debut of this young Brazilian artist is beautifully in step with the somewhat pious trend of making art out of almost nothing to circumvent the big, bad art market. In video, collages and typewriter drawings, randomness rules, and the centerpiece makes everyday magic from fans and bushels of bright tissue-paper circles. Tanya Bonakdar Gallery, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 414-4144, tanyabonakdargallery.com, through Oct. 14. (Smith)    DARIO ROBLETO: 'FEAR AND TENDERNESS IN MEN' Minus the checklist, these works come across as mawkish facsimiles of conventional 20th-century assemblage, 19th-century funeral wreaths, homemade reliquaries or folk art. Their impact expands as you read the lists of materials involved: all kinds of artifacts of American wars, from shrapnel and battlefield dirt to soldiers' letters used to make pulp. But it all remains too visually inaccessible, in addition to being a bit presumptuous about the keepsakes of people no longer alive. D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-9460, through Oct. 28. (Smith)    * SARA VANDERBEEK: 'MIRROR IN THE SKY' Ranging through 20th-century culture, this talented young artist pushes set-up photography and photo appropriation in directions at once worldly and highly personal. By building, lighting and photographing little stage-set constructions festooned with cut-out images, buttons, beads, trinkets and sometimes glitter, she creates poetic, strange amalgams of sculpture, collage and photo montage, and cuts Modernism down to size but also reveals it to be a Pandora's box of ideas. Max Ernst, Paul Outerbridge, Karen Kilimnik and Carol Bove are among the ghosts in these diminutive machines, which nonetheless run on their own steam. D'Amelio Terras, 525 West 22nd Street, (212) 352-9460, through Oct. 14. (Smith)    Last Chance    Guillermina Baiguera and Julian Gatto This gallery has changed its location but not its smallness, which is important to its craft-based, private-feeling, nostalgic-utopian aesthetic. The work of Guillermina Baiguera and Julian Gatto, from little watercolors to hand-size embroideries, exemplifies it. Little Cakes, Little Gallery, 625 East Sixth Street, Apartment 1B, East Village, littlecakes.org; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)    'The Filipino Roots of Minimalism: Leo Valledor and Mario Yrisarry' We owe Mitchell Algus for yet another historical rescue with this show of two painters who had a strong New York moment decades ago, then disappeared. Based on what's here, their shared Filipino background was less important to their interesting, and unalike art than the fact that they were both born in the 1930's, were abstract painters in the city in the 1960's, and exhibited at the Park Place gallery, along with Sol Lewitt, Edwin Ruda, Robert Smithson and Mark di Suvero. Mitchell Algus Gallery, 511 West 25th Street, Suite 206, Chelsea, (212) 242-6242; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)    * DANIEL LEFCOURT Against most odds, these beautifully made paintinglike configurations of strips of medium-density fiberboard painted black transcend their resemblance to the Minimalist get-me-out-of-painting paintings of the late 1960's. Their variety and needle-thin incised lines add layers of ideas about measurement, drawing and space, both real and illusionistic. They land squarely in the present, where abstraction is neither a dead horse nor a sacred quest, because they are primarily about looking. Taxter & Spengemann, 504 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-3540; closes tomorrow. (Smith)    'Mapquest' Elena Sorokina organized this group show for the activist art Web site artwurl.org. Most of what's in the gallery, by individual artists and collectives, is graphics-oriented, information-intensive and, in the current ''interventionist'' way, obliquely polemical. The show continues on artwurl.org itself. Performance Space 122 Gallery, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 228-4249; closes on Monday. (Cotter)    NEUE Galerie: Gustav Klimt: Five Paintings From the Collection of Ferdinand and Adele Bloch-Bauer  . Klimt's 1907 gold portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer, lately acquired by the billionaire collector Ronald S. Lauder, reportedly for $135 million, is now aptly installed like a trophy head above the mantelpiece. She's half queen, half Las Vegas showgirl. A perfect New Yorker. She temporarily hangs with four other Klimts, including a second Adele, painted in 1912: a slender, sinuous, Coke-bottle-shaped figure, more chaste than carnal. 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, neuegalerie.org, closes on Monday. (Kimmelman)    SARAH OPPENHEIMER: 554-5251 In the latest labor-intensive, wall-piercing installation to treat the gallery space as a malleable object, portions of the white cube have been sliced open and seemingly formed into two enormous tubes. Part tunnel, part basket and mostly plywood, these cut through the space, revealing the storage area and windows normally hidden from view, and requiring some walking in a crouched position. P.P.O.W., 555 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 647-1077, ppowgallery.com; closes tomorrow. (Smith)    * Mark Wagner and C. K. Wilde Mark Wagner and C. K. Wilde -- collagists, collaborators and co-founders of the Booklyn Artists Alliance -- may or may not make money from their art, but for sure they make their art from money. Mr. Wagner works with green-and-white United States currency, Mr. Wilde with a rainbow of international tender. From tiny pieces of both they assemble intensely detailed pictures of staggering virtuosity, with Mr. Wilde specializing in cut-and-paste remakes of Goya's ''Disasters of War.'' Pavel Zoubok Gallery, 533 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 675-7490, pavelzoubok.com; closes tomorrow. (Cotter)    ANDY WARHOL: MAO Whoever added the colors and brushwork to Andy Warhol's silkscreen images of the chairman, now 30 years dead, seems to have been having a good time. The surfaces have more life than usual for the master of art-as-business production, even if the show lacks one of Warhol's really, really big Maos. L&M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020; closes tomorrow. (Smith)    ALEXI WORTH: COUPLES A prominent bald head, somewhere between a boxed-in apple by Magritte and the smooth pate of a de Chirico mannequin, dominates several of these quirky paintings, which are as notable for the weirdness ascribed to both representation and human relations as for the discreet formalism of space, scale, tone and surface. D C Moore Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 247-2111; closes tomorrow. (Smith)

lead_paragraph: Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition.
